ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Thats pretty much it. Virtual seminar

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like I really got some insight on the idea of tragicomedy and the concept of waiting, both of which I want to tackle as a playwright. I also gained new knowledge on writing technique and critical thinking.

Probably how to "talk" about theater? I came into the class not knowing anything about theater studies, and now I think I'm more aware of the nuts and bolts of it and how they could be integrated to my own artistic practice.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think its fun and super engaging. I really love this course and this professor.

I think the seminar should be in person though. Zoom fatigue is so real.

In the beginning of the class, I'm still trying to find my ways how to read Greek tragedies and I relied more on random study guides that I found on the internet to figure out what was going on. I think it would be good to point out those references for students with zero background in theater studies so they could catch up on their own pace. I also learned a lot from Branden Jacob-Jenkins' Octoroon and thought the play could manage to tackle multiple layers of sociocultural issues, so I was wondering if the course could introduce more of contemporary plays?

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I just feel like there needs to be an in-person component. Trying to look at a computer for 2 hours to discuss plays can really take a lot out of you.

I like the part when we had to read the scripts out loud and was wondering if we could do that more in the class? I also actually like it when we had to read Brecht, so I was thinking if there's a way to incorporate theories here and there whenever we read new plays.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very much so. I think more people should take this seminar. Its really interesting material.
Yes if you want to know more about theater studies. I came into the class to know more about theories surrounding performance art and I think the class managed to do that.
